text:
I am not too big on veggies, but I CRAVE this dish!!!  First, FRESH, steamed grean beans are key!  I reduce the sour cream to 3/4c as others have suggested, reduce the salt to 1/2 tsp, add black pepper, and 1&1/2 tsp garlic powder with the salt & sugar. I use a large can of french fried onions and mix 1/4-1/2 can into beans, the rest I crush with the cracker topping and extra melted butter.  I add extra cheese (like most cheesy recipes I use), and mix some into the beans.    This can be mixed together ahead of time then thrown in the oven 30 minutes before serving.

text:
I tried this recipe twice.  The first time I made it as printed.  The onions were crunchy and raw, it was salty, and the flour made it too thick.  I tried it again, incorporating suggestions from previous reviewers.  I sauteed the onion in the butter until tender and translucent, and I reduced the salt and the flour by half, and added half of the cheese into the beans mixture.  It was much better the 2nd time!

text:
Absolutely Amazing!  I made this for Christmas exactly as the recipe is written, as I always try to do first, and then I made this again today, as a request by my husband for his regional meeting luncheon.  The first time was really great with simple go to ingredients, but the second time with a little extra energy and personal preferences added....was to die for.  The serving dish at the luncheon was all but licked clean.  My husband even found one of his crew scraping the serving spoon to ensure all that was to be had was had!  Too funny.  The second time I made some minor changes.  I used approximately 2 lbs fresh green beans which I steamed just shy of perfect since they were going in the oven as well, I used two 8oz blocks of Cabot (absolute hands down best cheese ever) seriously sharp cheddar (whatever reviewer said there was too much cheese would not be able to survive living at my house!) mixing about 4 oz into the beans, I minced my onion so there would be no large bites in my finished casserole, I added several turns of course ground black pepper, added about 1/2-1 t of garlic powder and finally used the French's Onions at my husband's request.  The casserole was loved by all and I was finally not the one taking food home from a covered dish!  Thank you so much Amy this is my new go to favorite for holidays AND covered dishes!

text:
This was good, but I think my green bean casserole taste better.  They are very close, but you need to saute onions in butter until soft add flour, salt sugar and dash of pepper. Remove from heat add sour cream.  Spread over green beans and top with swiss cheese. Bake until cheese melts.

text:
The recipe would be fine as is, but it's superb if you saute onions in butter first. When I make this recipe, I use fresh green beans from my farmer's market. I steam them first, using chicken broth instead of plain water. While they are steaming, I cook the onions in butter until transluscent, then add the flour, sugar, salt & pepper, cook 1 minute, then turn off heat. Then add sour cream and 1/2 the cheese in the saute pan. Pour this mixture over the beans in the casserole dish, add the other 1/2 cheese, then the crackers & butter. I could eat the whole thing myself, it's so delicious.

Excellent! Four stars because there is so much cheese.  We love cheese as much as much as the next person; however, this is way to much. If you are a moderate cheesse person and concerned with fat, use 1 cup, the taste will still be there. If you are a cheese lover, use 1 1/2 cups, that should be more than enough.

text:
I keep forgetting to make these and oh yes...this is by far the best green bean casserole ever. My husband said it's way better than using cream of mushroom. I  read other reviews before hand and this is what I gathered: sauteed the onions (I always use red onions) with the butter first until translucent, cut back on the salt by half, 1.5 T. of flour, half cup of cheese mixed with the green bean, spread 3/4-1 cup cheese then sprinkled a tad bit of the crushed cracker and finished off with French's fried onions (add some during baking and add more after).

text:
FANTASTIC! I believe a good or creative cook never needs to use cream-of-anything soup to make a great dish! I am so happy this does not use cream of mushroom soup (or yucky canned onions - OOF)! I made three minor changes: I used seasoned bread crumbs on top instead of crackers, I put just enough cheese on top to cover the casserole, and I lightly cooked the onions before adding to the dish (just lightly because we like onions and the crunch they give!). I also doubled the recipe. It's great!!! I used canned green beans (would be wonderful with fresh also) and they were just fine even for a holiday dinner. This is a great recipe as is, but I do prefer the seasoned bread crumbs to crackers. Please don't alter any other ingredients! Try it first with ALL of the sour cream and sugar! If you love this type of casserole, then you won't be disappointed! If you normally like cream-of-whatever soups OR dislike green bean casseroles.....this probably WON'T be for you! We just love it - thank you!!!

text:
This was planned for a Christmas party of 11 so I was shocked when I realized that this recipie made just enough to fill a 9 inch square glass dish.  I ran back to the store for more stuff and the next dish I added cream of mushroom soup instead.  Both turned out well, but the fisrt batch with sour cream was ALL GONE on the first pass.  No leftovers.  I could tell a difference in the flavor between the two.  What's interesting is that my family has made GB casserole for years with cream of mush and they loved the sour cream mix better.  Cooked on 325 for an hour.  Nice crust on top.

text:
I quadupled this recipie for an office potluck. I was hoping to bring some home, and I was close to not getting my wish. Everyone loved it. I added french onions into the mix and put some on top as well for texture. Make SURE that you get french cut beans and not whole cut. There is a huge difference in how the casserole holds up by using the wrong bean.

text:
In high school my friend who enjoyed cooking use to drone on about various casseroles and I had to ask him exactly what a "casserole" was.  My Japanese mom just didn't make them.  Five years ago at Thanksgiving time, my then BF's 11 yo. nephew went on and on ad inifinitum about "Green bean casserole."  I told him I didn't know what it was so he insisted I try it at Turkey Day dinner.  I didn't like it much.  Later, my current BF mentioned how he wanted it so I found this recipe, and behold--This was great! I halved the flour and salt.  Sauteed the onions before adding, and stirred in half the cheese and sprinkiled the remaining on top.  I now like green bean casserole.

text:
Made scaled down versions of this and 2 other green bean casserole recipes looking for an alternative to the one that uses cream of mushroom soup.  My family (5 of us) all taste tested all 3 and this one won.  The only things I did different was that I used frozen green beans (cooked and drained first), stirred some of the cheese into the beans, and stirred in some bacon bits I had cooked up for one of the other casseroles.  I did get the request to add more bacon to it next time so that is definitely a good addition.  The only other thing that I would do different is cut the salt a bit.  Cheese is very salty plus I added the bacon which is also salty so mine was overly so.   I like the thought from some of the other reviews of sauteing the onions first and adding a bit of pepper and garlic, too, so I may try that when I make it for Thanksgiving.  Overall a good recipe though.  Very flexible for altering to tastes.

text:
First off let me state that I am not a casserole maker.Secondly I would not want to be critical of anyone's grandma but, with this recipe it wasn't even considered.This dish has it all,moistness,crunchiness and flavor too.I made this the first time for half the family who were home and they all had seconds and said this one is a keeper.I made it the following week for everyone and made a few changes.Instead of canned green beans I steamed fresh green beans beforehand.The original substitutes the old standby of canned mushroom soup for a sour cream based sauce and I left that alone.Also the french fried onions were substituted for crackers. I had french fried onions on hand and used them as the topping for taste and presentation.I reduced the amount of cheese by half and it still was good.To keep the mushroom flavor I sauteed some fresh sliced button mushrooms in garlic butter. I used the drippings from this pan to lightly brush the crackers then sprinkled with fresh herbs diced small and added one tablespoon of Mrs Dash seasoning. This gave the dish a wonderful mushroom flavor and the crunchy seasoned crackers on the bottom kept the dish from being too wet.This is a great side dish whether you stick with the recipe or tweak it just a bit.

text:
I've made this recipe twice and both times it was excellent. The two times that I've made it, I left out the flour, used less salt, added pepper and the first time I used garlic, like some other's have suggested. The first time I thought I had done something wrong because the sour cream seemed to curdle, but I realized the second time around, that I think the flour serves a purpose: to prevent the curdle effect and to hold the ingredients together.  I used Jack cheese and topped with the crunchy French's onions like others have suggested, I think really no matter how you make it or what you add or change, it's still basically green beans and sourcream and it's so so good! Thank you to Amy Barry for the great recipe.

text:
I LOVED this recipe.  I usually don't like green bean casserole, but I chose this to make for a food day at work.  Everyone loved it.  I took some suggestions of some other reviewers.  I sauted the onion and a clove  of garlic in the butter before adding the flour.  I also added the cheddar cheese in with the green bean mixture instead of putting it on top.  The cheddar cheese would get hard if you're not eating it right away.  It turned out great!  I think I will probably add another can of green beans next time though.  If you add the cheddar cheese with the rest of the mixture, it could use some more green beans.

text:
I had to make a few changes to make this gluten free, and it came out fabulous.  It is so much better than the dreaded cream o' mushroom soup goo version.  I sauteed the onions first, and then eight chopped mushrooms, then added them to the sauce.  I used two tablespoons of potato starch in place of the all purpose flour.  I followed the directions, but used crumbled gluten free potato chips in place of the cracker crumbs.  This is definitely a gluten free keeper.

text:
This casserole was awesome! The only modifications that I made were to lighten it up. My husband and I are on weight watchers so I needed to bring something to Thanksgiving dinner that wasn't going to completely kill our diets. This is what I changed: I used light butter, splenda, FF sour cream, fresh green beans,reduced fat round crackers, and the best part: light velveeta for the topping instead of the shredded cheddar cheese. (light or fat free shredded cheese will harden and not give a good cheesy topping) Everyone enjoyed this recipe-even the non dieters!

text:
I made several modifications to this recipe so I can't really say my rating applies, but it was excellent! We definitely liked it better than using canned cream of chicken/mushroom soup. I made the following changes: used 1lb blanched fresh green beans (could have used 1.5-2lb with the amount of sauce there was) added 1c chicken broth to the roux before adding the sour cream, used 2t onion powder instead of diced onion (I was in a hurry), and used the traditional French Fried Onions instead of Ritz crackers, mixing some in and using some for topping. Love the addition of the cheese!

This recipe was THE best green bean casserole ever.  Instead of using the crackers they suggested I used French's fried onions on top.  It was fabulous.  I also a small amount of bacon bits (for flavor) and cut up mushrooms to cook with the rest of the filling.

It was the biggest hit of Christmas dinner this past year. :)

text:
This will turn anyone who hates green bean casserole into a lover. The trick is to use fresh steamed green beans instead of canned. If you use canned it is really salty, too mushy and the sour cream is way too strong. But if you use fresh green beans everything is perfect. I also mixed the Ritz with the classic French fried onions because I like a really crispy top.

text:
I detest mushrooms so i was excited to try this out. So, like others suggested, I took out half the flour and salt, kept sugar. Subbed salt for seasoning salt. Added black pepper and garlic powder. Just took the onions out (this time, next time I'll put them in 'cause I love me some onion). I steamed fresh green beans in my pressure cooker before mixing everything. Added all the sour cream because I added a bit of extra beans (no such thing as too much sour cream for some of us). Then  added a little more than a cup of cheese to the mixture and therefore added a Lil less then half cheese on top (to equal the 2 cups). Finished it off with a homemade french onion recipe (just milk n flour basically) and wala! Delish! I'll give it a four because of all the editing.

text:
Okay, I have a confession. I've been making this casserole for at least 4 years and I still haven't left a review.  So, as I am compiling my grocery list to make this for TWO potlucks this week, I felt like it was time.  This is my FAVORITE green bean casserole. I have never been a fan of cream of mushroom soup so this was always on the bottom of the list to make or eat during the holidays.  Now, I make it ALL the time!  

After 4 years, I've tweaked the recipe just a bit to my liking but the base recipe is still delicious!  

I saute the onion for 3-5 minutes and toss in some fresh minced garlic for the last 30 seconds or so before I make the roux.  I mix about 2/3 of the cheese in with the green beans mixture.  After topping with the rest of the cheese and the cracker mixture, I add some crispy fried shallots.  There are NEVER leftovers!

country:
None
text:
I love this recipe!  When I make it, I omit the sugar and the crackers.  I fry up three or four pieces of bacon and saute the onion in about a TBS of the bacon fat, a teaspoon of butter and the flour.  I then add the green beans (I think fresh are better), the onions, sour cream, the crumbled up bacon, a cup of the cheese, and some of the French's fried onions that are usually traditional with this dish.   Season to taste.  This all goes into a casserole dish, and it is topped with the remainder of the cheese and sprinkled with some more French's fried onions.  Even my husband, who HATES sour cream, loves this dish!  A definite keeper!

text:
Followed this recipe except for substituting a shake of onion powder for the onion (don't like onion pieces in casseroles).  This was pretty tasty! I had been wanting to try this for a while since my husband loves green beans but hates mushrooms so won't eat the traditional GBC.  He liked this as well but thought it was a little too 'zesty' which could be because I used extra sharp white cheddar (all we had on hand).  I also took the reviewers suggestion of mixing the cheese with the green bean sour cream mixture and am glad I did.  I will probably make this again but next time will use a very mild cheddar, a little less sour cream, maybe 2/3 cup, and the traditional french fried onion topping.  The cracker topping was great but I missed those crunchy onions :) Thanks for a great recipe for those who don't eat mushrooms!

this was wonderful!  i did a dry run before thanksgiving and used the recipe scaler to downsize to use about one can of beans.... i followed what others had said and put half the cheese in the bean mixture and the rest on top. i was in a hurry and so i put my fresh onions that i had diced in just a very little amount of margarine/butter and put in the microwave for a couple minutes so they would not be crunchy... then i put the whole casserole minus the crumb mixture in the microwave for about 4 minutes to get it hot and bubbly and then popped it on the oven until the crumbs were browned.. this was great.. much better than the usual green bean casserole.... thanks to the creator...;-)

country:
None
text:
Am testing recipes to be used for Thanksgiving.   First, I made this the day before (minus the topping), the next day added the topping, one side french fried onions, the other side crushed crackers mixed with melted butter.  It was great made the day before (always important for Thanksgiving).  My family liked the crushed cracker topping better, which surprised me.  Crushed crackers it is!!!  I did use frozen french cut green beans, and as reviewers suggested, I did saute the onion in the butter in the first step.  I also added sliced button mushrooms and would continue to do that in the future.  As with any recipe, you have to adjust to your families preferences.  I serve 30 for Thanksgiving and this recipe will be on the table this year.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
GOOD EATS!!!
No more Cream of Mushroom soup!!
After reading previous reviewers comments, I too sautéed the onions in the butter (actually Country Crock). Added the flour till smooth, the sour cream and 1tsp.salt, pepper and the sugar. Tasted for seasoning..a bit "one note" so added one tsp. garlic powder, several dashes of paprika..and yes a few dashes of soy sauce. Re-tasted..much more savory with more depth of flavor. Added the steamed green beans (Birds Eye "steamers"..2 bags microwaved in bag for 6 minutes first). Mixed all together with about 1/2 cup of cheddar, along with french's fried onions. Baked 15 minutes then topped with fried onions mixed with 1/2 cup of cheddar and finished the last 15 minutes of baking, I had noticed in the pictures that many of the tops looked a bit too brown, adding the topping the last 15 minutes of baking made a golden brown crunchy topping. Yum..perfecto

text:
My sister-in-law was hosting Christmas dinner and I was told that I was to bring the green bean casserole. I know these are often a holiday tradition for many families but I had never even tasted one before! Ack! What to do? Ran to allrecipes.com, pulled up green bean casseroles, and sorted by rating. Never has failed me yet!

 I made the recipe with only one small alteration, using french fried onions instead of crackers at the suggestion of another reviewer and the result was delicious. So much so that my sister-in-law's family called me prior to Christmas each year to ask me for the recipe for "the green bean casserole that is better than my mom's." Allrecipes.com to the rescue again.

text:
This is a delicious alternative to the mushroom soup/fried onion version. After reading several reviews I sauteed the onions in butter until they were soft before adding the flour. I also think the salt can be reduced by half. I mixed half of the cheese into the bean mixture as well and used the other half for the topping. If you are not afraid of calories, add some crumbled bacon to the topping for an extra treat :)

If you like this dish but always thought the basic recipe (cream of mushroom, canned beans, onion stuff) could be improved than you were right!  I recommend following this recipe but cutting out some of the heavier ingredients (maybe use light sour cream and 3/4's of the cheese called for).  You could also add some fresh mushrooms.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is by far my favorite green bean casserole recipe. I found it in a magazine probably about 10 years ago.. it was a hit, and my grandma even considered her casserole retired after that. The only reason she continued to make it was because my sister didn't like this one.

The recipe I have has a very slight adjustment to this one; it calls for corn flakes as the topping instead of crackers. I love the crunchy bite of corn flakes mixed in with the great taste of the rest of the casserole. Also, I often sprinkle a little bit of cheese throughout the rest of the casserole.

One problem I've always had with this recipe is that there's a lot of liquid still in it. I don't know if that's just the nature of this recipe or not, because I often let the beans drain for an hour or so... if anyone has a hint on this for me, that would be great!

text:
Absolutely DELICIOUS! I made this for Thanksgiving for the first time, and it was DEMANDED that I also make it for Christmas! Even family members who don't usually like green bean casserole were going for seconds and thirds! I followed other reviewers' suggestions by: using frozen french-cut green beans (not canned), adding bacon and doing 1/2 a cup of sour cream and half a can of Cream of Mushroom soup (well, I like it a bit more creamy, so I probably used about 3/4 cup sour cream and 3/4 can of the soup). I also added 1 1/2 cans of French Fried onions to the green bean mixture, and 1 1/2 cans to the topping (increased the butter to 2 tbsps to the topping because of this). Yum yum yum, this has become a traditional dish at our holiday gatherings.

text:
Simply THE best green bean casserole, ever. I didn't measure any of the toppings, just topped the sour cream-green bean mixture with enough of a shredded Mexican cheese combo to cover it generously, subsituted bread crumbs for the crushed crackers and also covered generously, then tossed as many onions as would fit on top. Watch closely in the oven! Within 15 minutes, mine was browned on top, so I covered loosely with foil and let it warm up in the oven for the remaining 15.

into the grean bean mixture, and put the remaining cheese on top.

text:
This recipe was fantastic.  I brought it to our Canadian Thanksgiving dinner received at my in laws and everyone was so impressed including my discriminating father in law.  The only thing I did differently was added a few more onions and at the request of another person, mixed the cheese to the beans instead of putting it on top. I made it for 12 servings instead of the original 8.  It was a huge success!  I will be making it for Christmas as well.  Thank you!
Also note: I wanted this recipe to be low carbohydrate as well...so I eliminated the flour and crackers and it still turned out great!!

text:
I've made this twice now: 4 stars for the recipe as written and 5 stars with the recommendations of others. Saute the onions in the butter first before adding the flour and seasonings. I included garlic and black pepper in the seasonings. Also, many recommend cutting back on the sour cream but instead, I used an extra can of the French green beans. I incorporated about 1/4 of the cheese in the mixture and also used french fried onions (with a little melted butter to coat) as a topping instead of the crackers to give it that classic crunchy topping. Perfect!

userID:
14770988
Display Name:
debagreen
isPro:
False
followersCount:

1

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was very excited to add a "new" green bean casserole to my repertoire, we were all pretty much over the old standby.  I took the advice of Kimar and halved the flour and salt, sautéed the onion first (I would have done anyway) and mixed most of the cheese into the sour cream.  All of those things worked well.  I couldn't leave well enough alone, though.  I decided to add about 2 cups of mixed, slice mushrooms to the onion sauté (this required a bit more butter/olive oil, about another 2 tablespoons) and let that cook for a pretty long time, probably around 10 minutes, they were very well caramelized.  I then proceeded with the rest of the compilation but caved and added about a 1/2 c. of Trader Joe's fried onion bits to the sauce, as well as about a 1/2 cup of 1/2 and 1/2.  I also layered the green bean mixture with some of the cheese, that worked well, incorporating it nicely into the casserole.  I added the remaining cheese on the top, under the cracker crust (I added some of the french fried onions to the crackers, as well).  When I make this again, I'll eliminate the top layer of cheese and incorporate it into the sauce, it just was to "hard" with the cracker crust.  All in all, the comments basically ran like this; "Who made the green bean casserole, it's awesome!"

text:
This was awesome last year. This year I revised it just to be different.
In stead of fresh onions, I used 6oz of French's Fried Onions, reserving1/2c for casserole topping.
Added 4oz cream cheese.
Added 1c shredded cheddar cheese.
Added 1 can each of cream of chicken condensed soup and cream of celery condensed soup.
Added 3c chicken broth (I use coffee water with bullion cubes or paste).
I mixed all ingredients except the 1/2c fried onions, which I put on top of the casserole before baking.
My clan loved it!

country:
None
text:
I think it's funny how polarizing this recipe seems to be. If you love it, you REALLY love it. Those who don't, REALLY don't. Growing up I always HATED green bean casserole because it was always made with cream of whatever, but I am in love with this dish. I only make a few very minor changes based on my personal taste. I prefer to steam fresh green beans rather than using canned, I sautee the onion, I only use about a cup of cheese (and only on top), and I am obsessed with fried onions, so I put those on top instead of the crackers. Oh, and I maybe use a little less salt and add pepper. Overall, this recipe is one I look forward to having with Thanksgiving dinner every year.
Review:

None
text:
This recipe is great all by itself.  I've recently gone vegetarian and it's a great dish to make along with roasted potatoes.  Very filling.

I made the following changes so it would be healthier (with almost a negligible effect on taste):  fat free sour cream, 1.75 cups of fat free cheddar cheese, green beans without any salt/sugar added, and reduced fat crackers. I also sautéed the onions first as other reviewers have recommended.  Next time, I'll probably add more onions and use fresh steamed green beans as opposed to canned green beans.

None
text:
I used a pound of fresh, steamed greenbeans instead of canned - next time I'd use a pound and a half, plus cut the beans smaller. I'd also add more onion - maybe a third of a cup instead. I'd also cut the cheese down to 1.5 or maybe 1.25 cups instead. Instead of normal Ritz crackers, I crumbled those thin ones - the Parmesan Herb flavor - worked out great. I also topped it with a few of the cheddar fried onions - definitely add that again.

UPDATE: I used canned this time, still topped with fried onions, decided to keep the cheese the same. They were the most-requested "seconds" at my Thanksgiving table.

text:
This is the best green bean casserole recipe on the planet. I don't even need to try the others to know this! Every single time I make it, people RAVE about it. "Mmm, oh my gosh, this green bean casserole is AMAZING!" and "I don't even like green beans, but this is SO good!" and "I've NEVER like green bean casserole, but I LOVE yours!"

I do three things differently from this recipe: Fresh steamed green beans instead of canned (or frozen is better too), French's fried onions on top instead of crackers, and about a cup of shredded cheese mixed in with the green bean mixture.

People love the cheese!

This dish is now a staple in my holiday menus!

I made this for our family Christmas Eve Party, the pan was cleaned!! I followed some of the other reviewers' advice. I reduced the sour cream - I put in a little over 3/4 c. I mixed part of the cheese into the beans (1-1/4 C). I also mixed in a 1/4 of a can of the french fried onions. I made another dish on Christmas Day for my husband who had worked on Christmas Eve. He thought it was a little too salty so I will reduce the salt next time. Overall this was a BIG hit and I will definitely make it again.

text:
This dish was a big hit at Thanksgiving this year and two out of four at the dinner don't even usually enjoy green bean casserole (or "GBC" as they disdainfully called it). However, I persuaded them this was not ordinary "GBC" and they both found that they enjoyed the dish so much, it was the first of the leftovers to get completely gobbled up!

Two thumbs way up for this dish. As for alterations, I used one cup of Colby Jack and one cup of Cheddar since I enjoy the combination of the two better then just Cheddar. Will definitely be making this again and again.

text:
As my husband said, this is really good and really rich tasting because of all of the sour cream. The only reason I'm giving this 4 stars instead of 5 is that it was missing the awesome crunchiness of the French fried onions from the standard version. I would make this again but use regular cut instead of french style green beans, add some milk to cut down on the sour cream richness, and use fried onions.

text:
its a 4 as is/for me a 5 and a keeper with a few changes. I have made the old cream of shroom version from Campbells.Like the flavor/hate the sllimy canned soup consistency of that one. This one I love the creamy base and found the flavor a tad bland and with too much salt....so I have mixed the 2. I now use this one with only 1/2 tsp of salt and added the 1/4 tsp pepper and 2 tsp Worchestershire sauce from the Campbells version...now it is "just right" for me! I really DO like the crunchy fried onions from the Campbells version...so instead of putting the onions in this one (though it IS admittedly healthier!) I used the fried onions on top instead.

text:
This was fantastic. I was skeptical about using crackers instead of the traditional fried onions, but I went ahead and did it. As it turns out, I actually PREFER the crackers!   Also, i mixed 75% of the cheese in with the beans and i'm glad i did.  Here's a tip that worked great for me: i used the cheese grater on my onion. I had my onion ready in about 15 seconds, and the size/texture of the onions were perfect for this recipe (i'm not a huge onion chunck fan).  So Good. I made this for thanksgiving and it's one of the few dishes that didn't have any leftovers. I'm probably making it again tonight!

amyi

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2638087.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i've pre-made this for tomorrow (thanksgiving).  i bought fresh green beans, snapped & steamed them.  i browned the onion as well as two cloves of garlic in butter and then set them to the side as i made the "gravy."  i added the full amount of salt and sugar as fresh green beans are not already salty like canned ones.  after making the gravy i added in the already browned onions & garlic and then greek yogurt (rather than sour cream... i live in italy and we don't have sour cream, greek yogurt tastes pretty much just like it though).  after mixing everything together i actually mixed the cheese (provolone and mozzarella as we don't have cheddar) together with the green beans (as per previous reviewers recommendations).  i topped it all off with the ritz (we CAN get those in italy!)/butter combo and popped it in the fridge until tomorrow.  i can already tell that this is going to be GOOD!  i will follow-up after tomorrow's feast! :)

text:
I was looking for a recipe to use some canned green beans I had for awhile and I found this recipe. I made half the recipe with the ingredient amounts I had. I liked that the recipe was a casserole but it had, "no canned soup!" The downside is it is not the most healthy of recipes, so it might be better as a holiday type casserole. And, it was a tad oniony for my taste, and I wished it were a little bit more creamy. Even though I chopped the onions into a very small dice, some even still seemed slightly crunchy. I didn't have the butter crackers in the recipe, so I used oyster crackers and added a tsp. more butter and a pinch of salt to them and it worked fine.

This was a fantastic recipe! A lot better than the usual Campbell's soup recipe. I live abroad and was asked to bring a dish typical of American holiday traditions to a Christmas party, so I chose the green bean casserole. I was unable to find the ingredients for the Campbell's recipe, so I searched for an alternate recipe. This will always be my green bean casserole recipe. text:
MIL asked me to bring the greenbean casserole for Thanksgiving, so I thought I'd give this a try. I read the other reviews, and made a few modifications...mixed in a cup of the cheese with the beans and sour cream...sauteed the onion and a handful of chopped baby portabellos...mixed crushed ritz with some french fried onions for the topping...and it was a huge hit! All the family loved it, said they want it for Christmas dinner too! Oh, and I made the casserole on Tuesday night, without baking, stuck it the fridge till thursday and baked it 35 minutes, it was great! I give the recipe 5 stars, even with my modifications, because without the base recipe, I'd have had nothing to play with!

text:
Delicious!! I made this for Thanksgiving and got my dad and brother to actually eat veggies!  I followed the recommendations of previous reviewers and reduced the sour cream to 3/4 C, reduced the salt to 1/2 tsp, added black pepper, powered garlic, and mixed half the cheese (1 C) into the beans.  I probably didn't need any salt as the cheese was salty enough. Also next time I might add some half and half to the beans since it was a little too thick and not really "saucy" but still so good.  Definitely a new family favorite!

I made this for a family gathering recently, and they all loved it! I did make a few minor adjustments to the original recipe. I sauteed the onions and one finely chopped red bell pepper (mostly for some extra color) in the butter before adding the other ingredients. I also stirred some additional shredded cheese into the bean mixture before transferring it to the baking dish. I loved the added crunch that the cracker topping gave the dish. This one is definitely a keeper. Thanks!

favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2716434.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for a Christmas dinner test-run.  Everyone loved it.  Like other reviewers, I added black pepper and garlic powder, reduced the sour cream to ¾ c., reduced the flour to 1 T., and reduced the salt to ½ t.  I also sautéed the onion until translucent before adding it to the flour.  I used French fried onions rather than crackers alone and mixed approximately ½ of the can of onions with the green bean mixture and crumbled the remaining ½ can and the crackers on top of the casserole.  I’ve never made green bean casserole before, so I was very pleased when this came out a success!

I liked the flavors, but the crackers weren't as good as the traditional fried onions.

text:
I will never make the traditional green bean casserole again!!  This was a hit with my family for Christmas.  I did as others suggested...I sauteed the onions first.  Cut back to 3/4 cp sour cream, 1/2 tsp. salt, added 1 tsp pepper and 1&1/2 tsp garlic powder.  I added cheese and fried onions to grn bean mix.  I put more fried onions and ritz crackers in a large ziplock bag, added the melted butter and smashed it all up together for the topping.  Easy and no crumb mess to deal with.  This was the only dish I personally made this year....purchased ham and other sides from honey-baked hams...but this was the dish everyone raved about!

I mixed in half of a large can of french fried onions to the beans. I mixed the cheese WITH the beans (not on top). I topped it off with the crackers and more french fried onions. SO GOOD!

This turned out awesome. I made a couple variations, but followed the recipe for the most part: I sauteed the onions in a tablespoon of olive oil to carmelize them a bit before adding them to the butter/flour/salt/sugar mixture. Also, I reduced the salt to only 1/4 teaspoon and used canned green beans with no salt added. I used sharp cheddar cheese. This will be the only way I make green bean casserole from now on!

text:
This casserole is FANTASTIC! So much better than the traditional mushroom soup/french fried onion one. I have been making this casserole for the past three Thanksgivings, and it was such a hit, that both my Mom and my sister have asked for the recipe and now make this one instead of the green bean casseroles they had been making for their holiday dinners. The only thing I would recommend is to cut back a little bit on the sour cream, as it contains almost too much of it. Also, this casserole works very well if you prepare and cook it the night before Thaksgiving and reheat it for Thanksgiving Day.  It will definitely save you some time if you do it this way.

text:
I was really looking forward to this dish on Thanksgiving and impressing everyone and it was the least touched dish and no one even wanted it to take home (boo hoo). I really put a lot of effort into our Thanksgiving meal and make everything homemade and thought this would be much better then the standard old green bean casserole, especially with all the rave reviews here. I just can't figure it out, it was soggy and not very good and I served it straight from the oven and followed the recipe to a "T". My husband searched longingly for his french fried onion green bean casserole and was very disappointed in this. Looks like we are going back to the tried and true standard one for Christmas! I really try to give good reviews and don't get disappointed much with what I've gotten here (it's my husband's fav website only because he gets to be the guinea pig in my cooking!). Anyway, my suggestion would be to make this and see if you like it first, before using it for a big dinner with guests. Everyone was disappointed at my house. Sorry!

text:
YUM!! These were a big hit at my New Years dinner! Everyone liked them better than the mushroom soup recipe, I know I'll be making these instead from now on. I had 8 different dishes and 12 guests  and 1 person don't eat beans and my husband didn't have room on his plate, this dish was emptied! The only thing I did different was I omitted the onion and lightly sprinkled on a little garlic powder, used Friendship brand sour cream as it is super creamy, used cut style green beans instead of the french and mixed 1 cup cheddar into the bean mixture and sprinkled the other cup of cheese on top. I doubled the topping by using half of Ritz garlic butter crackers and half Toasteds butter crisps Delicious! I think I might double it for the next big gathering, wish I had some leftover! Thanks Amy and to Grandma!!!!

text:
This is by far the best green bean casserole anyone I have served it to has tasted.  It is requested that I bring it to every outting or BBQ we are going to.  I do one thing different with the recipe.  Instead of adding cheddar cheese, I cube up 1/3 block of velveeta and cook it with the green bean mixture on the stove until just melted.  It really makes a creamy cheesy side dish.  If I could give it ten stars I would.  Thank you Amy Barry for sharing this recipe.

This is one of my favorites, but I make a few modifications. Most importantly I always always use FRESH green beans (my family likes them crunchy so I do not steam them fully beforehand). There is never any of this left over- it disappears almost immediately! Thank you (and your grandma!) for such a great dish!

userID:
2223580
Display Name:
sheila
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/917697.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful, Easy and delicious. I just love this, i do however have a sour cream hater in the family - so i have had to alter this.. I saute my onions (and I add a handful of mushrooms) until translucent in the butter first then remove with a slotted spoon.. First and foremost, i must have frozen french cut green beans. Canned just won't do. I use Philadelphia cream cheese spread (in the tub-NOT brick) with 2 to 3 tablespoons of milk then I add a bit of powdered garlic and a small mix of black and white pepper  all stirred nicely in my very deep pan.  I put the two tablespoons of flour in a resealable bag add my slightly damp green beans, cooled onions and mushrooms then shake to cover finally adding to the pan that is cooking nicely on low heat- bringing it up to medium heat and stirring well! then its transfer to baking dish .. now i scale back on the shredded cheeses because I've used the cream cheese by about  1/2 cup. then follow recipe as usual.  if you hate sour cream and its taste this may be an option for you (not of course if you hate cream cheese too though!) another substitute - heavy cream or half and half, but if you use the heavy cream or half and half, you may need to add a bit more flour. As written this is a jamming good green bean casserole! NO one recipe is ever universally loved nor even hated - think about what you and your family really like and adjust for their tastes - and now... I'm craving  this casserole! thanks for posting!!

text:
The entire time my non vegetable eating son was shoving fork fulls of this in his mouth he said "I can't believe I'm eating vegetables"
 I used red onion because it's all I had. I added most of the cheddar cheese into the casserole and save about 1/2 cup for topping. I also had some french Fried onion from the awful green bean recipe I tried. I added some into the mixture and some on top with crackers    Oh and I used frozen petite green beans, I added them frozen into the mixture although they had pretty much thawed by the time I got them into the oven.  I found I needed about 55 minutes until the green beans were tender.  This was so delicious, I can't wait until tomorrow so I can eat the leftovers! Thanks Grandma!!!

text:
Okay, I have a couple of suggestions, but you could make this exactly as-is and people will fall in love.  Despite green bean casserole being a nostalgic food favorite with a distinct flavor that this takes a sharp departure from, I have never once heard that someone wanted it the way they had it when they were a kid, after having tasted this masterpiece casserole.  I don't think I've made this once without it being regarded as the highlight of the evening's food by all parties.

So, what can I suggest to essentially improve on perfection?  MAKE MORE!  Seriously, no matter how much you make, it won't be enough, but I always make at least double.  In addition, I double the crunchy topping because it's my favorite part.  The Ritz crackers are great, but I've experimented a bit with that, most notably with everything Ritz crackers and Cheez-Its, and my favorite so far was the Cheez-Its.

10/10

text:
My family loves this recipe, we followed momma_s recommendations of  Reducing sour cream to 3/4c, reduce salt to 1/2 tsp, add fresh cracked black pepper, and 1&1/2 tsp garlic powder with the salt & sugar. Large can of French fried onions and mix 1/4-1/2 can into beans, the rest crush with the cracker topping and extra melted butter. Mixed ahead of time until ready to go into the oven for 30 minutes.

Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOOOVED this!!! Tired of the "typical" green bean casserole, I decided to try something new this Thanksgiving - and boy am I glad I did! Even my (canned) green bean-hating husband liked this!!! My dinner guests also liked this quite a bit and asked what made it so unique (and yummy!). I pretty much followed Amy's directions to the letter with the exception of a couple (minor) alterations. My biggest change was how I prepared this. I sauteed my onion in butter FIRST, then added the flour, sugar and salt and cooked this mixture for a minute or two. I added HALF of my cheese to my green bean mixture and the rest layered on top as directed. My final changes were to add a 1/2 t of ground black pepper / t of garlic powder (when I added the flour, etc.) and a cup's worth of French's fried onions (1/2 to my green beans and the rest along with my crushed cracker topping). Thanks for sharing, Ms. Barry! I just can't rave enough about how good this was. :-) With my changes, this will most definitely become a regular tradition at my holiday dinner table!

text:
I made this recipe a little different than the instructions but I am sure the original is just as good- if not better.  I used boiled fresh green beans, added a clove of diced garlic at the end of sauteeing the onion(before adding the flour to be sure they were good and soft), used crushed saltines instead of buttery crackers, and did not have sour cream so used 4 oz cream cheese and 1/2 - 3/4 cup of milk until I got the right consistency of sauce.  It was so amazingly rich and cheesy, I loved it.  Thanks for this recipe, it will be my go-to recipe for green bean casserole from now on.

text:
This was really tasty. I pretty much stuck to the recipe, except:

- Sauteed the onion first before adding anything else
- Used fresh green beans (which probably doesn't matter much)
- mixed Frenchs fried onions with the cracker topping, and topped with more onions after serving.

This tastes wayy better than the cream of mushroom soup version.

We made a gluten free version by substituting rice flour for the all purpose flour and for the topping you use FunYums which are gluten free.  We mixed the cheese in instead of putting it on top but also put a little bit extra on the top.  Everyone said they liked it better then the mushroom  soup version and we liked the Funyums even better then the standard french fried onions.  We'll stick to this version from now on.

text:
This recipe is fabulous! I've searched for a green bean casserole that does NOT call for any type of mushrooms/mushroom soup or french fried onions. I just made this today to try it out before Thanksgiving - and I just can't stop eating it!! We are onion lovers so I used 1/2c onion, but other than that I followed the recipe to the letter. I'm not sure if Allen's is a regional (southern) brand, but I used Allen's seasoned Italian cut green beans which are by far the best canned green beans around - they're so flavorful. Don't hesitate about making this recipe. It's amazing!!!

text:
This is a winner! I have always been a big fan of green bean casserole, but have found most of them to have too watery a consistency. This was the reason my husband told me this year that he did not want me to make a casserole for Thanksgiving, because he didn't like the usual Campbell's Soup recipe. I was determined to find a recipe he would like, and this is it! The sauce is thick, creamy and flavorful, but not overpowering to the beans. I used canned green beans, and added french fried onions and a little cheddar cheese to the sauce. Everyone raved over it at Thanksgiving, even my mother in law, who is a fabulous cook, asked for my recipe! :) Will definitely be using this again and again!

I did end up adding French fried onions (at the request of my husband) as well as using the butter crackers and instead of cutting back on the sour cream as some sugested, I simply added an extra can of green beans, and I think I could have easily added another with it remaining deliciously creamy. All in all, this recipie was a huge success on my very first attempt, and got eaten up extremely fast!

Display Name:
Shelley B.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was a good starting point for me.  I read through reviews and made a few changes of my own too.  First, I sauteed 3 sliced strips of bacon in my pan, then added some sliced cremini mushrooms to sautee.  When they were soft and brown, I made a well in the middle and added my butter and flour for the thickener.  I then stirred in the salt, sugar, chopped dried onion, sour cream, and about 1/4 cup of heavy cream.  I added about 1 1/2 quart jars of green beans (from my family's garden that they can).  Tossed to coat and then added 1 cup of the shredded sharp cheddar, also stirring to distribute.  Poured into a 9x13 dish, topped with remaining cheese and crackers.  Baked in a 375 oven for about 20 minutes.  Came out great and it was one of the most eaten dishes at our Thanksgiving dinner!

country:
None
text:
This was a great alternative to the classic (yet unappealing) campbell's green bean casserole.  I thought the sauce mixture blended well with the green beans without giving the the over-salted instant casserole flavor you get with cream of mushroom soup.  I think two cups of cheese is a little excessive for this (adding that much cheese to a casserole this small just means there's a lack of flavor and the dish needs cheese to cover it up) and would recommend doubling it if you want to feed ten people with it. A good modification would be to omit the cheese on top and only include maybe 3/4 c. in the filling.

text:
Hooray - a change from the icky fried onion casseroles!  I sauteed the onions with some garlic in a bit of olive oil, added fresh green beans and then added the flour mixed with the other dry ingredients (halved the salt as others suggested), leaving out the butter entirely.  I used fat free sour cream, fat free shredded cheddar, and low-fat Ritz crackers.  I will probably use reduced fat cheese next time, as the fat free does not melt very nicely.

text:
This has got to be one of the BEST recipe I've made thus far. The only two minor changes that I made was I used FRESH green beans (par-boiled) & then once the green beans were coated with the ingredients from the skillet, I transferred it all into a bowl and mixed in the two cups of cheddar cheese--this allowed for a nice cheesy goodness with EVERY bite! The buttery cracker crust is definitely a heavenly touch.  My family went to bed fantasizing about this particular dish, just to wake up and have it for breakfast the next morning--this was the ONLY reason they didn't finish off during Thanksgiving dinner....enjoy!

text:
Doubled the recipe.. I made some alterations as per the suggestions of other reviewers. I decreased the sour cream slightly, but then discovered that by doing that I wasn't really left with something that had enough sauce, in my opinion. I added tablespoons of half and half to make it creamier, and enough sour cream until it didn't seem so dry. I used fresh steamed green beans and mixed half of the cheese in with the beans. The other half I put on top with a full can of French fried onions. I also tossed some cooked bacon in there too. I guess I made a lot of adjustments, but kept the spirit of the dish! I barely had any leftovers from a dinner of only 6!

country:
None
text:
I gotta tell you.. I have been getting RAVE reviews on this casserole for years now and I HAD to post a review.

I love the recipe as it is, but I've definitely made some adjustments.. first..

I use frozen french cut beans. I saute my onions in the butter first, then add the rest of the ingredients with no reductions when the beans defrost.. the extra flour is absorbed.

I also add extra cheese and some of the crackers to the beans... I love the crunch that comes from that and the sauce it produces is marvelous

U can make this ahead and let it sit.... it only takes 30 minutes to heat, and the kitchen smells MARVELOUS while its cooking. 

My family asks me to bring this to EVERY function we have. I love that even the kids will eat this!

Well, we had an early Thanksgiving day this weekend and I have to give this one a 5 stars. Even the kids liked it. It was all gone by the end of the meal!!! My son even said it was the best part!! What!!!??? I cried, but he made up by clarifying "of the sides that is" I brined the turkey with a brine recipe from this site and that was the best part :), but this side really made the spotlight. I don't like green beans casserole at all and neiher the kids, however, for some reason I always end up making it, just as part of the Thanskgiving a tradition and it always goes to waste!!!!! Not this time. I added a few small dollops of light cream of chicken soup and used Fat free sour cream, I used fresh green beans and added an extra can of french style canned beans. Delish and now I can have a light dish for poultry, fish etc. Thanks for the recipe!
Update: Just to say I am printing this again. It is now a tradition on our Christmas/Thanksgiving dinners and Kids request it ALL the time as odd as that sounds!!!! Then say YUM!!!

A worthy alternate to the standard cream of mushroom recipe!

text:
This is very good.  We stuck to the recipe to try it out for our upcoming Thanksgiving dinner.  The crackers don't seem like they'll be enough, but they really go a long way.  It's very "sour creamy", so I would cut back on that.  We diced our onion into VERY small pieces to avoid undercooking, and it turned out great.  I did miss some of that mushroom soup flavor, but this was a wonderful alternative.  For the real Thanksgiving dinner we'll use fresh green beans instead of canned, and less sour cream.  Great recipe!

text:
I've made this 4 times since August for family gatherings and have had about a dozen requests for the recipe from people that weren't at any of them.  I found that it's very easy to double everything and bake in a 9 X 13 stoneware cake pan.  I even made it with reduced fat sour cream and no one noticed a difference. At the first get-together, I made one casserole of the classic onion version and one of this.  Without a doubt, this was the favorite.

text:
I cooked this fot my church for a Wednesday night dinner and it was a big hit!!!!  I made enough for 125 and I did not have any left.  I used the super large size regular cut green beans instead of french style and I completely omitted the salt.  I added garlic powder to the mix and I added garlic salt to the cracker crumbs.  I used 5# sour cream and 5# cheddar cheese to 4 super size cans green beans.  I also sauteed the onions in butter and I did not use any flour at all.  It was thick enough without it.  I will prepare this again.  Thanks

text:
Very quick and easy and extremely tasty. The ideal green bean casserole for a busy dinner with many guests. My experience though - having made it yesterday for 9 people (6 adults and 3 children) - is that it yields only 8 servings rather than the 10 servings. Or my guests were especially hungry! If I made it again I would probably calculate the ingredients a little more generously. Other than that: a certain winner. Even my mother-in-law asked for the recipe!

text:
This was great!  I made it to bring to my parents' house for Thanksgiving dinner.  It was a hit!  I added more sour cream (but my family and I LOVE sour cream, probably more than the average person).  I also mixed most of the cheese in with the sour cream and beans.  I also added garlic salt, which was not a the best idea, because it made it a bit on the salty side, for my taste.  Next time I will not add any salt and use either fresh garlic cloves or garlic powder.  But I will definitely be making this one again and again!  Fast, easy and delicious!!

text:
Just have to let everyone know--this is still 5 Stars in our book! It's a "must" for family gatherings. They request it by name. It’s so much better than the traditional variety. First, I like using the French cut beans. Second, I hate cream of mushroom soup. Third, butter and flour make a better sauce than canned soup any day! If you find yours “lacking” then add some seasonings (I personally love Mrs. Dash).  I've made it for two Thanksgivings in a row and am looking forward to this year! Usually, I omit the cheese in this recipe because I forget that it calls for it (yes, I have this memorized). I use fried onions, so I think that no one notices any lack of flavored toppings. Boy, “Grandma" was a GREAT cook!

text:
I made this last Christmas and it was a hit! I grew tired of the standard cream of mushroom and fried onion green bean bake. This recipe really mixes things up and the sour cream adds a whole new dimension of flavor. Because we’re in Texas, I add diced jalapeño pepper and diced fresh garlic to the diced onion mixture and sauté for a few minutes...really brings out the good flavor without the harsh burn associated with the jalapeño.

This was much better than the traditional canned soup and French fried onion way but I would make the following changes:
Cook onions first
Fresh green beans
Stir all cheese into beans
Assemble the day before and add 12 Ritz crackers on top instead of 9 right before baking.

I followed the recipe, with the canned french green beans - the only difference was I added more cheddar cheese to the top. I was pretty underwhelmed with this recipe, it was bland and I didn't like the melted cheese - it made the dish feel really heavy and greasy - which is an abomination for me to say because I am a cheese addict. I think I'll try it again with fresh green beans as other posters suggested and a better more flavorful cheese (using less this time), but to rate the recipe as is I give it 2 stars.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4413509.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last year for Thanksgiving dinner and everybody LOVED IT!!! This has now been requested to be at every family holiday feast even when we are traveling across states! I did tweak this recipe just a bit. First, I get fresh green beans and cut them and then steam them. I use 1/2 teaspoon salt, 1.5 teaspoons garlic powder with the sugar. I then use 1/2 container of French Fried Onions crushed instead of a regular onion. Add the entire cup of sour cream and about 1 cup of the cheddar cheese. Mix the green beans to coat and then transfer into greased casserole dish. I layer with more cheddar cheese and then I mix crushed ritz crackers and the other 1/2 of the French Fried Onions crushed together for the topping. Don't forget to add the melted butter to the top (I use 2 tablespoons vs 1 because of how much topping I put on). Delicious and easy recipe!

text:
Try at lest once if you like the classic green bean casserole.
I only gave it 4 stars because not the whole family loved it. We are very classic green bean casserole lovers.
I've made it twice now the only big difference was I added the crispy fried onions instead of the cracker and butter mixture and added pepper. This time I made it with carmelized sliced onions and and a whole clove of garlic which I just cooked with the onions and took out before I mixed it all. 
I loved it and it satisfies my cravings for green bean casserole.

Display Name:
Jayme Cox Bruce

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have had my eye on this recipe for years, and finally decided to try it for Thanksgiving this year, rather than the standard cream of mushroom soup recipe I always make. I really liked this! I thought it was better! I made a few changes, per our family's taste. I sauteed the onion in the butter, because I don't like crunchy onion. I also added some black pepper and garlic powder to the sauce. I mixed half of the cheese into the casserole, as I always do in my regular recipe. And green bean casserole is not the same, to me, without the french fried onions. So, I mixed some into the casserole, as well as crush some into the cracker crumb crust. My 8 year old daughter loved it and gobbled it up! If I hadn't been so full after my first helping, I would have eaten seconds, and I know what I'm eating for lunch tomorrow! One thing to note for next time: I don't think it needs as much salt, so I will try using half the amount next time, but that may be because of my addition of the fried onions, which are salty anyway. In my regular recipe I also like to include water chestnuts, and I will try that next time. I loved the addition of the garlic powder, and next time I will be sure to have enough fresh garlic that I can use that instead and saute with the onion (I used the last of mine in our mashed potatoes).

text:
This is the only GBC you should ever make!  I don't use the onions most of the time b/c usually I'm running late and they give me headaches. I just use French fried onions on the top (if the onions are cooked, I don't get a headache. Migraine trigger.)  When I use the onions on top, I don't use the butter crackers. Also one of my best friends is gluten free, so the last time I made this I just excluded the flour and it worked just fine.  I make it with fresh green beans as well. I love this recipe b/c it doesn't have cream of mushroom soup in it so it's easily turned into a completely healthy, organic side dish. Sour cream = good fats! (Made from

text:
So I was a little lazy when it came to this recipe so instead of making the roux and adding in the sour cream I used a can of cream of mushroom soup so that the casserole would be think still. I also wanted the French fried onions that were nearly impossible to find (I should have known lol) so I substituted them for the cracker crumbs. All and all I turned this into a delicious Frankenstein of a green bean casserole and I think it turned out really well. Either way, seeing as this recipe was the main inspiration I thought it necessary to rate it very highly.

My family loved this version and they normally won't touch green bean casserole. It is also great because we have family who are allergic to mushrooms and can't have the other version. text:
Just tried this recipe today for our early family Thanksgiving, it was a hit! I did everything as directed, except I made my own corn bread, no mix. One mistake I did make is forgetting to omit the 1/4 cup sugar called for in the corn bread recipe. In the future I may add a tablespoon or two of sugar, but not a quarter cup. In-spite of that, the dressing was delicious! I've never had corn bread stuffing before, neither has my family (we live in WI and corn bread stuffing is not a tradition our family), but we were all pleasantly surprised.

text:
I made this for the first time for Thanksgiving, then again for Christmas Eve with some slight changes the second time around and it was perfect. Definitely sauté the onion in the butter first.  I also reduced the cheese to 1 cup and incorporated half of that to the green bean mix and then sprinkled the rest on top. And lastly, added about 3/4 of a can of French fried onions to the cracker/butter topping.  My mother in law was just raving about it and thats a huge compliment coming from the best cook I know.  Thank you, Amy for getting us hooked!

text:
This recipe hands down beats your average "green bean casserole" with canned mushroom soup. I used fresh green beans, boiled them till they were barely tender, also sautéed the onion in olive oil, I also added about 1/3 of the cheese to the bean/sour cream mixture, and I topped it with the crackers and a can of fried onions. It turned out superb, everyone loved it!!! I think next time I will try it with jack or Swiss cheese, because the sharpness if the cheddar cheese kind of took over the dish, but it was still great.  I made mine the day before, took it out and let it get to room temp that morning, and just added the topping before I put it in the oven to save time on thanksgiving.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the same recipe that my mother-in-law typed on an old 3 by 5 card in one of those ancient hard-plastic recipe box from the early 1960's.  After upgrading the terms her old recipe became this one! I would still grate the onion, though, and collect as much onion juice from the grating for the cream sauce. It makes for a tastier flavor. Instead of cheddar cheese, try swiss cheese--it pairs MUCH BETTER with the green beans (and shredded swiss is now available at the grocer's). I like the idea of coating the green beans with the sauce in this recipe; the old recipe wanted the beans layered with the cheese, and the cream sauce poured over the top of everything. I think coating the beans with the sauce ensures better coverage.

This was SO good!  I used frozen green beans and lightly boiled them first before mixing into the sauce. I substituted half full fat homemade yogurt instead of using the full amount of sour cream. I think using the real onions really made the dish taste much better--please don't substitute dried onions if at all possible!

text:
Excellent!  I just made this and have to say that I am thrilled to have a recipe for green bean casserole that uses non-pantry ingredients!  I didn't have sour cream on hand so I made a roux with heavy cream, flour & milk.  Also instead of onions I used shallots (again, what I had on hand) and once I tried the sauce, I decided to skip the cheese all together (the cheese by the way was the ingredient that first enticed me to try this recipe!)  I felt that the cheese would have been overkill and take away from the great flavors that were already there.  I don't think I'll ever use the stuff in the cans for my green been casserole ever again.  Thanks Amy & thank  your grandma too!  :o)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
For our DAIRY FREE home, this was a great base recipe to work from!  I took some advice from other reviewers, and some tricks that I've learned to alter this recipe to fit our lifestyle.  First, I used FRESH, STEAMED Green beans.....so good!  Then, I used 2 TBSP dairy free butter alternative and sauteed one small onion.  I used 2 TBSP flour, 1 TSP white sugar, 1/2 TSP salt, 1/4 TSP black pepper, and 1 1/2 TSP garlic powder (although next time I will decrease the garlic by 1/2 tsp.).  I then used about 3/4 cup rice milk and about 1 cup of dairy free sour cream alternative.  It made a fabulous sauce!  I couldn't stop tasting it =)  I will probably use it over pasta at some point.  Then, as other readers suggested, I mixed-in the french fried onions and topped with the onions as well.  I did not use any cheese, but that's because the cheese alternatives would have altered the flavor.  But from someone who used to put cheese in EVERYTHING, now that we aren't using it, I really don't miss it.

text:
Ok, heres the deal. My girlfriend does the cooking normally. My grandmother used to make a great green bean casserole and I wanted to bring back that memory a little for christmas so i found this recipe. I added about 3/4 cup of cooked bacon and I only added half the amount of the required sour cream. I then added a whole regular sized can of cream of mushroom soup. I CANNOT GET HER TO LEAVE ME ALONE ABOUT THE FREAKING CASSEROLE!!! She is begging me to make this again! Oh, and we used a combination of Ritz crackers and French fried onions. I also took the recommendation of another user and sauted 1/2 cup of onion into the garlic clove and butter before adding the flour.

Very easy and tasty.  We found it to be a nice change from the normal green bean casserole.   I cooked the onion in butter first then added the flour, salt and sugar.  I used two cans cut green beans and one can french style.  Once all mixed together I put it in the dish and covered with fried french onions.  Will make again!

None
text:
This was delicious! I have never had the other popular green bean casserole, so I can't compare the two, but everyone in my family was telling me not to waste my time making a green bean casserole with our Turkey dinner...but once they tasted it, everyone went back for seconds or thirds! I made a few changes: I only used 3/4 cup of sour cream, I mixed 1 cup of cheese in with the green beans and mixed the other cup with some french fried onions in the can for the topping (I did not use the cracker crumbs at all). I also sauted the onions ahead of time in the butter and added a handful of french fried onions in the bean mixture too. Delicous!!

I made this and a more traditional version (Green Bean Casserole 1) for two options at Thanksgiving. Most people who tried this and commented really liked it. Nobody did not like it that I am aware of. One said they still prefer the traditional version. I followed directions except I only put in 1 cup of cheese and stirred it into casserole (per other reviews), and I stirred most of a square box of fresh sliced mushrooms into the casserole. I also used a whole package of Ritz crackers and 4 tablespoons butter. I thought it was a nice spin on the traditional version, but similar enough that it still satisfies the craving.

text:
Doesn't taste like the "classic" casserole made with cream of mushroom soup; and with all that butter, it's not really any healthier either. Even evaluating it on its own merits (shocking, I know), it's not quite my cup of tea - I don't think the flavors of the green beans and the sour cream go together. My wife and unborn child seemed to like it, though, which is why I am giving it 3 stars instead of less. I mean no offense to the author of this recipe, I just want to warn people that if they're looking for a from-scratch version of green bean casserole, this might not be it.

text:
I was a bit concerned how this dish would turn out after reading other members' reviews, but it was absolutely fantastic!  My first time making it was for a Thanksgiving feast with friends- talk about a gamble!  The only things I changed was sauteeing the onions (added 1/4 cup chopped crimini mushrooms) first and mixing the cheese in with the beans prior to coating with the cracker crumbs.  It got rave reviews from the diners- this dish is now in my permanent recipe collection!

text:
This was absolutely out of this world!  The BEST dish on the Thanksgiving table.  Wow!  However, I must admit that I used much of momma_s’ suggestions, which is the “most helpful” review for this recipe – EXCEPT I did not mix cheese or French fried onions in with the green beans NOR did I add extra cheese.  I used fresh steamed green beans (HUGE difference), reduced the sour  cream to about ¾ cup, added black pepper and 1.5 tsp or garlic powder.  I mixed half a can of crushed French fried onions in with the crackers and doubled the butter at this point.  500 stars!  A winner!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
-2 lbs of fresh beans (blanch for 3-4 mins)
- 1/2 cup of diced onions (instead of 1/4)
- Fresh garlic (about 1-2 cloves)
- Like others mentioned, reduce to 3/4 cup sour cream,  add black pepper. Add fried onions to butter cracker topping. I use half the amount of cheese.

text:
I thought this was pretty good.  I made it for a friend's Thanksgiving get-together and I will say that someone specifically asked, "Who made the green bean casserole?  That was great!"  The sour cream adds a "tangy" taste.  I used the crackers, but I agree the friend onions would probably taste better.  I also sauteed the onions and didn't add as much cheese which were suggestions by others.  I might make it again...or might just make the traditional recipe.  This one is nice when you are looking for something different.

text:
Well...I reviewed this back when I made it, but AR didn't save the review. (?) So anyway, we didn't like this. We didn't even finish it, I'm sad to say. The sour cream absolutely overpowered everything, and tasted strongly of sour cream and not much like anything else at all. I like green beans (husband doesn't); he likes sour cream (I don't); neither of us liked this. I was bothered by the sour cream, he was bothered by the fact the sour cream did NOT mask the green beans enough. For contrast: I do like the green bean casserole that comes on the side of the French's onion can (but he doesn't like that either.) So I don't know what to recommend to people--some people WILL like this a lot (and the ratings reflect that). But some people will absolutely refuse to finish their serving, but then I guess that's true of anything! Thanks for the recipe, I really couldn't find anything wrong with it, it just wasn't for us :)

None
country:
None
text:
I've made this recipe again and again without any alterations. I tend to change up recipes constantly, but as far as I'm concerned, this one is perfect. The onions have always turned out soft (and I'm extremely sensitive to onions. I'd just as soon leave them out!), the sour cream amount is perfect, and the flavors blended together create a unique, almost tangy green bean casserole. I feel this definitely doesn't need the French onions that some people suggested and the cheese really adds something. I constantly crave this dish. Honestly, if you're going to make this dish, try it first without the alterations. You might be surprised at how incredible it is.

text:
I NEVER give 5 stars but with my modifications this is unbelievable.  So much better than the old Cream of Mushroom Soup Recipe.  3 Tbl. Olive Oil instead of the butter no salt no sugar Sauteed the onions Used Fat Free Sour Cream Only (2) cans of green beans 1 cup of shredded Cheddar 1 cup of sliced Mozzarella 1 cup of Fried onions instead of crackers Mix everything together except the cheeses. Add the sliced mozarella Add the Cheddar Add the Fried Onions FABULOUS!

text:
tasty recipe. I did not add the teaspoon of salt, but dusted it with some seasoning salt to taste. I sauteed the onion in the butter, added the flour and sugar and then mixed those into the bean/sour cream mixture. I only used about 1.5 cups of cheese and did not add the extra table spoon of butter to the crackers as they are already buttered and I don't think it affected the recipe. Overall, this was good but I may add some spices next time through for a little more oomph :)

userID:
2789304
Display Name:
Holly 'Draeger' Larson
isPro:

followersCount:
10

madeRecipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2658065.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As my 2-yr old would say, "Dee dee dee liddish!"  Made for Christmas after reading all the rave reviews.  I should have made a double batch.  Everyone loved it, it was gone fast.  I sauteed the onions in butter alone before adding, as others have suggested.  Also left out all but just a dash of the sugar.  Used 3/4 cup sour cream, which was plenty.  Used full cup second time making this, and I prefer with just 3/4 cup.  Also added the crunchy fried onions to the mix, and about half of the cheese, before baking.  Then added the rest of cheese on top, and some more fried onions on top, broiled on low for 3 minutes at the very end to get it a little crispy.  Oh yes, added about 1/8 tsp pepper too before backing.  Forgot it the second time and it really needed the pepper.  This is nice and creamy, fantastic, much better flavor than the standard creamy soup recipe.  Plus, much less salt involved, which is great for my dh with high blood pressure.  I rarely made this traditionally because of the high salt content of the cream soups, but now dh wants me to make this all the time.  A huge winner!

text:
Followed ingredients exactly, except sauteed the onion in the butter until soft.  Also, added some fresh ground pepper, but overdid it a bit on that (just a sprinkle would have been better).  I loved the flavors and texture, but found it a little too rich.  Next time, will cut down on the sour cream to 3/4 cup, and will try low fat sour cream.  I'll also add a few more crackers to the top.  My husband missed the french fried onion topping from the traditional recipe.  I didn't... I loved the crackers.  I think the cheese is just perfect: I used good quality shredded sharp cheddar. I agree with others that fresh green beans would be wonderful in this recipe.  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Velveeta!
I read a few reviews that spoke of the oils of the cheddar making the recipe greasy, so I used velveeta in it's place. As for other things I did, I heeded previous reviewers and used frozen whole green beans (thawed a bit with warm water), added fried onions (my favorite: 1/2 in the mix and the other 1/2 on top), and added fresh crumbled bacon in the mix and on the top.
Loved this recipe, and so did everyone else. With a mixed family Thanksgiving, I heard the most raving about this green bean casserole than anything else.

This is the first green bean casserole I've made and I altered the recipe a bit based on other reviews. I used frozen green beans and boiled them for a few minutes, then I cut them in half because they were long. I used french-fried onions instead of fresh onions. I also crumbled half of the french fried onions and mixed them with the crackers as noted in another review. I served it for Thanksgiving and it turned out great. My guests didn't believe it was my first time making a green bean casserole and everyone loved it!

This is great.  I steamed 2 lbs of fresh green beans the day before. omitted the onion, decreased the sour cream to about 1/2-2/3 cup, cut salt in half, added pepper and about 1 tsp garlic powder.  mixed 1/2 can french fried onion rings into beans, mixed other half with crushed ritz crackers and butter for the top. The recipe was OK, but not good or great. I made it exactly as described, and thought the sour cream flavor was too strong. Perhaps if the amount of sour cream was reduced, it would be more in balance. I really, really love cheese, but there was also too strong a cheddar cheese flavor for this dish. The basic problem is that there is not enough green bean flavor, and too much sour cream and cheese flavor. I want a green bean casserole to have green beans as the prominent flavor.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
4* on this one since recipe required modification to be a 5*.  Made recipe as written first time and modified it since. With all the cheese, any extra salt is too much.  1/2 the cheese + double the crackers - (no butter with the crackers for the top).

To make this, I saute the onions in the butter in a deep pot then stir in the flour.  I mix in the sour cream and sugar then the grated cheese and pre-cooked fresh (or frozen) green beans.  Spread in the baking dish and sprinkle crumbled crackers over the top.  Always, always, always get asked for this recipe.

ETA - over a decade  later, still a hit, now my daughter is out on her own and is making a name for herself bringing this dish to potlucks!

text:
I followed the recipe to the letter ... I always find it's disastrous to deviate when making a recipe for the first time.  My family does not eat cream of mushroom soup as it typically has MSG in it ... and I was looking for an alternate vegetable.  Thank you allrecipes.com for featuring this casserole.  It was by far superior to any green bean casserole I've ever had.  I did use fresh green beans rather than canned and there wasn't a single serving left after Thanksgiving dinner was over.  I did not find the cheese to be excessive and I loved the texture of the onions.  I will never make another green bean casserole again.

Everyone, including me, LOVED this recipe!!  I made it for thanksgiving and it was the first dish to go.  Everyone had seconds and thirds.  I followed the recipe exactly.  It was the perfect combination of everything.  I have been asked to bring this again for our Christmas dinner.  I hate the Cream of Mushroom/chicken taste in other recipes...so this was the perfect recipe for me.  I added enough cheese to cover the top...I didn't measure I just shredded right on the casserole. Oh..and I didn't add the crunchy top...I left it out because I forgot..lol
I made this the night before, stored it in the fridge and then baked for 30 mins the next day. YUMMY!!!
