I personally would have given this less stars, but their were some at Easter dinner who enjoyed, so...  I just missed the cruncy fried onions and enjoyed the original better, though if I were to make this again I'd make sure to use a better name brand cheddar cheese, I used a cheap brand and it seemed as though the cheese made a coagulated film over the top, and I also would have used more then the recommended crackers on top, and a bit less sour cream, but honestly, I'm going back to the mushroom soup casserole recipe.

region:

country:
None
text:
Green bean casserole is a tradition in our house for every holiday. After eating the standard for years, I will never go back. This recipe is so good that everybody is in awe trying to figure out what is different. The recipe is a must to bring along because people will definitely ask for it. I have made it twice. The first time exactly how it is directed and it was great. The second time off memory, so I goofed and forgot the sugar and stirred in the cheese, which I actually liked even better. I think it gives it a richer, creamier texture. You just can't go wrong. The ritz and sour cream completely do away with that processed flavor you get from the mushroom soup/french onion recipe.

text:
This was an interesting dish at my thanksgiving table. I used this recipe as a good solid base, although I used green beans that were blanched from the garden, and then frozen this past summer. I don't care for green beans actually but thought this dish was great.  I might add bacon next time, (1 strip cooked and crumbled) sauted the onion in butter, added flour,  beans, sour cream, and mild cheddar. I didn't get the compliments I thought I would get, which surprised me since I thought it was tasted warm and bubbly. Guess Thansgiving just has to much food. Would try again, as a side so the recipe shines more.

text:
I made this recipe for Thanksgiving the last two years, and everyone loves it. By reading the other reviews I did make a few changes. I used low fat sour cream, and only used 1/2 a cup, and mixed it with half a can of cream of mushroom soup. I also used the frozen french grean beans and the fried onions. It is so easy to make, and with the change of ingredients it is great.

We didn't care for this at all. I agree with the other reviewers who gave it a low grade - the sour cream is too tangy, it really isn't very creamy, and, we didn't like the rawness of the onion. We'll stick with the tried-and-tested. Thanks anyway.

text:
I gave this only three stars, because while it tasted pretty good, it wasn't worth the fat calories that the sour cream and cheese gave it. If I'm going to make a casserole, rather than just steaming fresh veggies, the taste better be worth the extra trouble and calories. This just wasn't in my opinion, even using just half of the original cheese called for and reduced fat sour cream. Also, unless you like very strong onion flavor, cook yours a bit longer than this recipe calls for.

None
text:
I used potato chips instead of crackers because my sister - in law is allergic to wheat.  I have also used plain yogurt in place of sour cream.  I use oil as supposed to butter(Using oil instead of butter makes food creamier).  In addition, I use frozen French cut beans rather than from the can.  My family says, however, to let green bean thaw before you make the casserole.  Although the recipe did not call for it, I add one or two cloves of garlic.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everyone raved at Thanksgiving. I had people calling and asking for the recipe. I followed some of the other reviewers suggestions. I used Cabot Seriously Sharp Cheddar. I purchased a 16 OZ block. I purchases frozen steamable green beans, 2 lbs worth. I steamed a minute less than the instructions to get them mostly done, but not all the way. I  sautéed the onions in the butter until translucent prior to adding the flour, salt, sugar and sour cream and adding the green beans. 1 added 1/2 cup of shredded cheese to the green bean mixture. I added the most of the remaining cheese to the top (I don't think I used all of it. I eyeballed it.) Lastly, on top of the cheese, I used a combination of both crumbled Ritz crackers mixed with butter and French's French Fried Onions. Baked according to directions. HUGE HIT!!!! New Thanksgiving staple. Thank you for the great recipe.

text:
This is wonderful! I was looking for a green bean casserole  recipe that didn't have the same old cream of mushroom soup. This recipe fit the bill to perfection. I must say I was skeptical of adding cheddar cheese to green beans, but it sure worked well here. One change I did make was with the topping. I had some Hawaiian kettle style potato chips - both Maui onion and mango habanero. I wanted a bit of a bite to the dish so I crushed the chips with a few of the butter crackers and melted butter. Amazing! I was afraid to use only the mango habanero chips thinking they might add too much of a bite. Next time that is all I'll use. The sour cream in the dish is enough to temper the spice. Even without the topping the dish was great, the chips knocked it out of the park!  Thank you for a great recipe. It is definitely my new green bean casserole go-to!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Everyone loved this dish, and asked me for the recipe.  I was serving 10 people, so I used 3 pounds fresh green beans, which I steamed.  I sautéed the onions in butter first, as others recommended, then added another 2 tablespoons of butter before the flour and sour cream.  It was a little thick, so added a couple tablespoons of heavy whipping cream, which made the perfect consistency.  I also mixed about 1/2 cup of the cheese into the beans.  Instead of crackers, my family loves the fried onions, so I mixed 1/2 of one can with the beans and topped the dish with a 2nd can.  I used a 10x15 pan, so I had lots of surface area for the remaining cheese and crispy fried onions.  It was excellent.

country:

text:
I made this recipe for Thanksgiving dinner and it was a huge hit!  Everyone wanted the recipe.  I did make modifications per other reviews.  I also increased the ingredients accordingly  as I was feeding more people. The main changes were:
1. Added 1/2-3/4 cup cheese into bean mixture ( I used 2lbs  fresh steam green beans) 
2. Sauteed the (red) onions before adding the flour.
3.  Added 1 1/2 tsp of garlic salt and 1tsp pepper  with the salt and sugar before adding sour cream.  I increased the flour/ sour cream to make more sauce in the bean mixture but not so much it was soupy with sauce. 
4. Added 1/2 cup of the french fried onions into bean mixture and the rest with the cracker mixtures with extra melted butter. 
5. Added in bacon bits to the bean mixture before topping with the cheese and cracker/french  onion mixture.

text:
I was looking for a homemade alternative to the traditional canned-soup green bean casserole recipe. This is it! Loads of flavor. The only change to the recipe I made was to eliminate the crackers and I used gluten free  crispy fried onions and cassava flour instead of wheat flour. Even my very picky daughter loves this recipe.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed some advice of others.  Used 2 lbs of fresh green beans in a lg pot of water with chicken broth.  While that was ccooking for about 10 min., I sauteed onions til soft.  Then I added flour, salt and sugar and cooked for 1 min.  Turned off heat and added 3/4 c sour cream and half of cheese and mixed it together.  Then added drained green beans and mixed it all.  Placed in casserole dish and topped with remaining cheese and sprinkled with french's fried onions.  Made it the night before and brought it to Thanksgiving and popped it into the oven.  This will now be our annual Thanksgiving dish, loved it!!!

text:
This was a FAVORITE at Thanksgiving. To save room in the oven, I cooked it in a crockpot on low for about 5 hours. I used another reviewers tip and that worked well. KIMAR said "I sauteed the onion in the butter until tender and translucent, and I reduced the salt and the flour by half, and added half of the cheese into the beans mixture."

Display Name:
Livvie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this dish several times and, each time, it's been a hit. I incorporated some suggestions, like cutting down the amount of flour from 2 to 1 tablespoon, adding pepper and garlic powder for a little more flavor, and substituting French's fried onions (crushed) for the round crackers and melted butter. I've also followed some directions suggested to saute the diced onions in the butter to soften before adding the spices, then allowing the mixture to cool before adding sour cream and half the cheese. I mix some of the French's fried onions in the mixture before putting in the oven. I also bake uncovered for about the first 15 minutes (until the top is golden and cheese is melted), then cover for the remainder of the time. After the casserole is baked, I add more cheese and French's onions to the top.

text:
Generally good, but I thought the cheese on top overpowered a lot of the other tastes. It was tasty, but I think I actually like the standard version of green bean casserole better. There was something lacking from this one. (Edited to add: I think what's missing is that the French fried onions add a level of crunch to the casserole that this one falls short of. The cheese and crackers make a crust on the top, but it's a different consistency than what I want out of a green bean casserole!)

text:
I make this every year and I didn’t know it was an actual printed recipe until I came across this one! My only difference is to sweat the onions first, then add some cream cheese to onions melt it down and then add the sour cream spice mixture let it simmer to meld the flavors. After that add fresh green beans along with French to get that home feel casserole texture, toss in a handful of sharp cheddar toss it about throw it on a pan sprinkle with cheddar and some Frenchy’s Onions all over! Delicious!

None
text:
I fixed the recipe as written but cut back on the salt, and I love salt, and added some garlic powder like one reviewer suggested. Something I do different for thanksgiving, I dice and fry bacon and add it to the mixture. I scoop the bacon out with a slotted spoon and fry the onions in the bacon grease to soften them. If you have bacon drippings left over you can use that in place of the butter to make your roux. I also mixed half the cheese in before transferring to the baking dish and put the rest on top.

userID:
22791035
Display Name:
Jennifer Hallmann
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5261102.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this several times, doctoring it a little each time.
I never measure...sorry.   THis one was the best.  I substitute fresh green beans.  Steamed so they are starting to soften.  (You could boil)

I sauted(I used olive oil this time) the onion, one jalapeno, garlic salt, black pepper, sugar, and chipolte seasoning, and a shake of ancho chili seasoning.  Stirred in the flour.  The the sour cream.  I used a mexican cheese blend.  I stirred about a cup into the green beans.  (I made 2 lbs of fresh green beans, so upped all the ingredients a bit).  I spread the green beans into a pam coated class 13 x 8.  Covered with a layer of Sam's club brand bacon bits (more like chunks).  Covered with cheese.  I make extra of the cracker/butter mix, plus I crush up some Fresj Gourmet Crispy Jalapenos (like the onions.)  It was dinner!  Will make next time with left over easter ham.  I made it 'medium/mild spicey" because my son is less of a 'hot' lover than I am.   IYUM!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe and great upgrade to the usual greenbean casserole. Only comments I would make are that 2 cups of cheese may be a bit much. As I was putting that layer on, it felt excessive. But, I only had a few ounces left, so I used it all. Next time, I may try using closer to a cup. The cheese to bean ratio seemed slightly off. Also, I like a crispy top, so I doubled the cracker mixture. Worked out well. Also, I went ahead and crushed equal amounts Ritz crackers AND French fried onions, to give it some of that traditional appeal. Buttering the topping ensured it came out crispy, not mushy. Received lots of compliment on the dish.

userID:
17957691
Display Name:
Nomospammam
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
662
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a fantastic recipe. The creamy base is a great tasting cream base! I could imagine creamed potatoes or corn or broccoli etc.. even pasta! I did make a few changes based on ingredients I had on hand. Since I didn't have canned green beans which are softer and pre-cooked then frozen green beans, I boiled a sleeve of frozen green beans in salted water till the color change to a darker green and softer. While the green beans were boiling, I melted butter in a skillet & sautéed (bag/frozen) pre-chopped onions, celery & Green bellpepper (in the south the veggie mix is called the Holy Trinity.. the base for most dishes) till soft.. stirred in the suggested seasonings, then added the flour & stirred to incorporate into the sautéed veggies.. letting it cook a few minutes to lose the flour taste, kinda like a thick light color roux coating the veggies. It was time to add liquid.. so I stirred in light sour cream. Btw I didn't measure anything just eyed everything but using the recipe as a standard. At this point I tasted the sour cream sauce and knew this was going to be a KEEPER. In a medium casserole dish mixed the beans & sauce & used some preshredded Italian cheese blend from a tub purchased from Sams club. And also shredded some cheddar to the top. Then mixed the crushed butter crackers into small amount of melted butter & sprinkled that over the top of the dish. Baked it at 350.. anyway I love this recipe & forget the canned mushroom soup, this is far better.

Made according to the recipe except for using fresh green beans, and it was wonderful except for the cheese on top.  That is too much cheddar and hardened when cooled a bit on the table.  Next time I will use just a bit (maybe couple tablespoons)  of fresh grated Parmesan added to the buttery crackers for the topping.  I boiled the fresh green beans in salted water for about 20 minutes and drained them well.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't like green beans and have never made green bean casserole. But in a panic for another veggie side dish for Thanksgiving, we turned to this recipe because of the simple directions/ingredient list and the rave reviews. It did not disappoint!!  So quick to throw together - we used home canned green beans we had in storage - and everyone loved it!! (I'll admit it wasn't half bad, despite the fact I don't like green beans.) Also loved that it doesn't use cream soup - which allowed me to sub plain Greek yogurt for the sour cream, thereby making it edible for my lactose intolerant family members.  Will definitely be making this again, but I suspect it would taste even better with fresh green beans over canned.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this twice now. The first time, I made it as written. I give a 3 based on the written recipe. The second time, I changed it a tad. First, I cooked the onions; I think they are gross and too crunchy if you don't. Also, I increased the butter used to sauté to about 3 tablespoons. I added garlic with the onions, cooked them, then added the flour. The remaining steps I followed except I mixed the cheese in with the beans instead of keeping it only on the top. I also mixed fried onions in with the cracker topping. The second round of making this, with those changes, made it much better I feel.

userID:

Display Name:
MaryBeast
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not much of a cook but we were assigned the green bean casserole for Thanksgiving. I read a ton of the reviews and made many of the changes mentioned. First, let me say that it tastes better than casseroles made with cream of mushroom soup.  Everyone like it, even the kids. I doubled the recipe and put the mixture in a 13", 2" deep casserole pan. I used three 24oz cans of French style beans. I reduced sour cream to 3/4 cup (1.5 cups total) and it really could have been reduced a little further. I was very creamy and rich. I sautéed the onions in the butter before adding other ingredients. I added a little more than 1 tsp of garlic powder and cut the salt slightly. I used very sharp cheddar and mixed half of it into the mix and put the rest on top. I also mixed in some French fried onions and added some to the topping also (didn't even use a whole small container). I did also add the crushed Ritz butter crackers on top and I would add even more next time because it added great crunch and flavor. I will definitely make this again next year.
Review:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My hubs loves green bean casserole and asked me to make it as a side dish for Thanksgiving. I looked through a few recipes but this one had so many great reviews, I decided to try it and it was a hit. He is so picky about what he will eat as his Mom made this throughout his childhood. He said that this was the best green bean casserole he has ever tasted and that made me very happy. So here is what I changed based on the feedback from other reviewers:
1. Sauteed the onions in butter first, then added the flour, salt, etc.
2. Steamed the green beans but left a little crunch
3. Used less sour cream - 3/4 cup
4. Used less than 2 cups of cheese
5. Used fried onions instead of the crackers

It as delicious and tasted very homemade!

text:
I've made this many times with fresh/frozen/canned green beans and fresh/frozen broccoli too. If using fresh or frozen veggies, I just cook or steam them before hand. Only differences: I sauté the onions first, use half the amount of salt the recipe calls for, and sometimes, if I run out of sour cream, I'll use 1/2-3/4cup sour cream and 1/4-1/2cup cream cheese and that is great too. I'll throw in cayenne every once in a while for a little kick if I'm making it for adults only and no kiddos. This is the only casserole my family wants at Thanksgiving and Christmas!

text:
I discovered this recipe two years ago on the 16th birthday of a nephew for whom I had forgotten to purchase a gift. As an uncle in good standing I didn't want to arrive without a gift so I asked his mother for suggestions. She told me green bean casserole was his favorite, was quick and easy to make, and suggested I make it for him. To say I don't like green bean casserole would be an enormous understatement! I never cared for this dish. But, I was out of time and unwilling to arrive empty handed so I girded my loins and headed for the pantry. No canned French onions! What to do? Search the internet for a crunchy French onion recipe. Yes, that's it. What a surprise! I thought the "classic" cream of mushroom and canned French onion topping recipe WAS green bean casserole. It never occurred to me there were other recipes. I had all the ingredients for Amy's recipe so....Everyone loved it! Especially my nephew!  And it still surprises me when I say "I LOVE GREEN BEAN CASSEROLE". More accurately, I love THIS green bean casserole. Thank you Amy!!!

userID:
4435246
Display Name:
Nattydred
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did not make this recipe exactly as is the first time, but I figured I would still offer feedback.

I read some of the reviews before making this. I was looking for a good base recipe to make green bean casserole from scratch, and this is excellent.

I followed some suggestions and reduced the salt by half, and sautéed the onions, which really makes a difference. I also removed the rue from the heat before adding the sour cream, and then added the green beans to coat them.

I made the rue with the measured amounts of butter, flour, sugar, and sour cream, and half the salt. I kinda winged it with the amount of onion, green beans, cheese, and crackers, and extra ingredients. I had the ratio of green beans to 'sauce' enough to be very well coated, but not too much.

I added my own twist to the recipe and used freshly steamed green beans, sautéed fresh crushed garlic with the onions, added mushrooms (steamed with the green beans) and crumbled bacon. I put some of the cheese into the mixture to get the cheesy flavour right through, and saved some of the crumbled bacon for the topping. I kind of winged it with the amount of cheese as I didn't want to overdo it. 

The casserole is not wet and soggy, but has a moist consistency that holds the beans together well that it's not sloppy when put on a plate. The cheese with the cracker crumbs on top makes for a nice crispy crunchy topping.

In all this is a great base recipe for making this dish from scratch. It is very simple and perfe
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2016-02-12T20:36:49.733
helpfulCount:
0

We liked this much better than the traditional soup and fried onions casserole. Great flavor and the topping cooks up yummy..  I'm not a fan of canned cream of anything soup so this was perfect. Makes a really large quantity and doesn't really seem as good the next day tho', the smooth textures gets rather chunky. Needs a more seasoning for our taste so I added a more pepper and some garlic salt.

While so many other reviewers have claimed that you need to sauté the onions beforehand, I found that this recipe was perfect just the way that it was written. The onions were soft in it, and it was very creamy. I did double the amount of buttery crackers that I put on top of it because I love a crunchy topping on a casserole, and I added French fried onions because I love them. Other than that, I did everything just as the recipe said to do. Last year, I made a very complicated green bean casserole for Thanksgiving dinner. This year, I made this one. It was super easy to make and delicious!

None
text:
My friends and family enjoyed this recipe with a couple of changes and additions.  Since there was no seasoning I added some and made a few other changes.  First of all, I parboiled two 16-oz. small bags of cut green beans instead of using the canned green beans.  I sautéed the onion in the butter before adding the flour.  I also added the following the sauce:  approximately ½ cup of half n half, 1/8 tsp. garlic granules, ¼ tsp. Mrs. Dash Tableblend seasoning and 1/8 tsp. ground pepper.  Overall this is a good recipe that you can start with and twist to satisfy your family.

country:
None
text:
After reading the reviews, I thought "why not try something new?" It was great and I love that it holds together and isn't soupy like the usual green bean casserole.

I did everything as directed, except a couple of things: I sliced the onions (instead of diced) and I let them cook a bit before I added the sour cream to the skillet. I eyeballed how much cheese I put on top, but it definitely wasn't 2 cups (maybe 1 cup). And I left some bigger pieces of crackers instead of crumbling it all. Other than that, I folowed as directed.

*Keep in mind, while this makes 10 servings, the dish was finished by 5 people. We had it alongside ham and 2 other delicious sides.

text:
I tried to make this and realized I had run out of most of the ingredients, so I improvised. Even with my failure to have the right ingredients, it was very good. I added garlic with the onions which I cooked before adding the flour. I didn't have sour cream, so I used half milk and half cream cheese. The cream cheese made it divine. Even with all my substitutions it was very good and as soon as I make it with butter and some cheddar, I'm sure it will be fantastic. I do have to recommend adding garlic and cream cheese for a little extra flavor. The melted butter (or oil) over the topping makes a big difference.

text:
I made this for a small "preT-day" meal for my husband and myself. I scaled the recipe down for 3-4 servings (whatever it took to get it down to one can of beans). It was delicious! I hate mushrooms (like I don't even want to be in the same county while someone is cooking them), but have always suffered through making the traditional casserole. I'm thrilled to have a new alternative. Now I'm just gong to have to resist making this all the time cause it'd kill my diet if I served it as often as I'd like. Oh, and as a bonus, it worked great  as the creamy veg element of the filling when I made the leftovers from the meal into pot pies. Those were so yummy, I served them two days in a row! THANKS so much for sharing!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe turned out great, but I made a LOT of changes based on the reviews. I used more onion (1/2 of an onion) and sauteed it and some minced garlic in the butter before adding the flour. I omitted the sugar because I didn't see the point of it and also added a little extra salt, plus some pepper and Worcestshire sauce. I cut the sour cream down to 1/2 cup and mixed 1 cup of cheese in with the green beans, then only used 1/2 cup of cheese on the top. Next time I might also try using fresh steamed green beans (but the canned tasted just fine). I think mushrooms would have been really yummy as well. The way I made it was delicious. I love the IDEA of this recipe (I was trying to get away from the creamed soup and canned onions), but it needed some work.

I made this exactly as the recipe stated minus 1/4 tsp. of the salt. All 3 members of my family didn't like it. They said there was way too much sour cream. I am a vegan so I didn't try any but decided to make it again using vegan sour cream and cheese. I didn't mind it but I did feel that it called for too much sour cream. If I make this again I will omit the sour cream and use almond milk to make a basic white sauce instead.

text:
Excellent! I hate mushrooms, so I never like the "traditional" green bean casserole. I made this for thanksgiving and my niece and nephew were fighting over who got the last spoonful and my brother asked me to make some more to have with leftovers.
I did do a couple of tweaks... I sauteed the onions in the butter a bit before adding the flour, used frozen instead of canned green beans, mixed some of the cheese in with the GB mixture instead of putting it all on top and used panko bread crumbs instead of crackers.
I WILL be making this again!

text:
I have used this recipe for the past 3 Thanksgivings. This year I made a few adjustments and it was over the top! I used Cabot Seriously Sharp White Cheddar to mix in the and top the green beans. I also used french fried onions since that is my husband's favorite part of a green bean casserole. Like many reviewers have mentioned, make sure to cook the onions in butter until they are translucent.  Once you try this recipe, whether you alter it or not, you'll never go back to nasty mushroom green bean casserole!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a nice alternative to the traditional green bean casserole with canned french fried onions and canned soup.  I tried it almost exactly as written, except I used frozen green bea. I think that using frozen or fresh green beans also improves the flavor over canned. Actually, I made one more substitution, based on what I had on hand:  I used bread crumbs coated with butter instead of the crackers.  I was surprised that even the small amount of sugar in the recipe added a hint of sweetness that was both subtle and interesting.  As others have mentioned, the result is a bit thick, so I added a little of the water in which the green beans had been steamed to thin the white sauce (since it is made with sour cream rather than milk, the dominant flavor is still that of white sauce made with milk).

text:
I love this recipe! I love green bean casserole, but sadly I have a mushroom allergy. So when I stumbled onto this recipe that didn't call for mushroom soup, I knew I had to give it a try. I followed some suggestions to cook the onions ahead of time before the baking and found that worked out really well. I like to make this recipe ahead of time and store it in the refrigerator overnight, since I tend to make this for Thanksgiving/Christmas. It saves me time the next day and I can just throw it in when I'm ready. My family loves this recipe, and I continue to get special requests for this casserole. Thank you for sharing!

Display Name:
heamhous

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614247.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was so excited to make this dish based on all of the great reviews, but was really disappointed with the final product. First, if using sour cream as the base in the "sauce" there is no reason to make a roux. I followed the recipe and found the sauce to be way too thick to evenly coat the beans - it was more of a paste. I added generous amounts of milk to thin the sauce, but this really didn't accomplish much. I went ahead, baked it, and crossed my fingers that the dish would at least be flavorful. Unfortunately this was not the case. I added more cheese, salt, garlic powder, milk (everything just stuck together!), some Panko for extra crunch, and baked it a little longer. These additions helped but I really think the extra cheese was what made this dish taste better. All in all, I will not be making this again.

This was a pretty good recipe that needs a few changes IMO. First off, this was really salty. My friends all LOVED it and the pan was scraped clean, but they live on fast food and they're used to the sodium. I mixed the cheddar in with the green beans instead of making one thick cheese layer as suggested by another reviewer, and I'm glad I did. Couldn't give it five stars even though it rocked and I'll make it again. Next time I'll use 1/2 tsp. salt and enjoy it more.

text:
I was never a fan on green bean casserole (It wasn't part of my childhood holiday food). I came across this recipe, tried it and fell in love. This is one of my favorite foods now. I triple the recipe for our family dinners because we love it that much. My husband who grew up on the traditional cream of mushroom casserole also prefers this. To reheat it we cover it with foil and bake it until it gets hot, then add new fried onions and crackers since the leftover ones get soggy. Excellent recipe and a holiday favorite for our ohana.  After making this recipe for a few years now the only thing I changed was sautéing the onions instead of using them raw.

text:
This was the star of our Thanksgiving table.  The recipe was easy to make, and turned out so much better than the cream of mushroom soup recipe.  I did make a few minor changes.  I was a little paranoid about the sugar so I only used 1/2 tsp.  It turned out great with this amount but I will use the full amount next time.  The other change I made was to use French Fried Onions rather than the cracker crust.  They turned out great, but it could be a little too onion-y if you aren't a fan.

text:
This recipe is amazing; I make it all the time. I add garlic (3-4 cloves) and double the onions though, and add black pepper and a bit of cayenne for seasoning as well. I also mix most of the cheese in with the green beans and then just sprinkle about a 1/2 cup or so over the top. And, 1 tbsp of melted butter for the crumb topping isn't nearly enough; I usually go with about 2 or 3. I've found that after these changes to an already great recipe, it is ridiculously awesome.

text:
I'm not a fan of canned green beans so I used fresh haricots vert. They need to be steamed a few minutes prior to assembling the casserole. As far as the flavors go, it is missing a little something. I put a few dashes of soy sauce after I added the sour cream to the mixture but it needs something more. I think the onions need to be caramelized or something. I also needed to add fried onions on top to make it feel like a traditional green bean casserole. I don't miss the canned mushroom soup at all!

text:
Turned out awesome! WAY better than the cream of mushroom soup version!!!!  I only made a few adjustments (personal pref.)   I minced my onion so there would be no large bites.  I added several turns of course ground black pepper, some garlic powder and some cayenne pepper!  Finally, I used the French's Onions in place of the ritz crackers (at my husband's request).  I added half the can of french fried onions IN the casserole and the other half I placed on top of the casserole during the last 5 minutes of cooking.  Yum!!  The casserole was loved by all........ no left overs!  :-)

country:

text:
This was a fantastic recipe.  I made if for Thanksgiving and everyone loved it.  I only gave it four stars because I think you should cook the onions in little butter before adding them to the rest of the ingredients.  Otherwise, they are a little too crunchy.  Also, I took several other reviwers' advice and mixed half of the cheese into the green bean mixture and the other half went on top.  This eliminated the thick crust on the top.  All in all, a great recipe.  Even my kids loved it!  We'll be making this next Thanksgiving for sure, although we might not be able to wait that long! Thanks for sharing your recipe!

Great alternative for people like me who don't care for the mushroom soup version. I've made it a few times and have found that if the onions are diced small enough they will cook and soften in the oven. I also like to use an extra can of beans and only about a cup of cheese. A sprinkling of paprika on top before baking gives the topping a really nice golden color.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'll admit I was skeptical.  I was looking for a green bean casserole for Easter that would "kick things up a notch".  This one sounded good, but once I got into it, I got scared of the cheese.  I used 3 pounds of fresh green beans, a whole medium onion, and the whole cup of sour cream.  I also added some fresh garlic that I chopped finely and sauted with the onions.  Instead of the cheese, I used the cheddar cheese flavored French's Onions, mixing half of the container with the green bean mixture prior to baking, and pouring the rest on top to bake.  It was good, but nothing impressive.  Then at dinner, I placed the shredded cheddar cheese next to it.  People melted the cheese over the casserole themselves, and it was amazing!  That being said, don't doubt the recipe!  Add the cheese!  The only good thing about leaving the cheese on the side was that people were able to add it to their own taste level.  I'll definetely make this again!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
11/27/14 - go easy on the cheese - like 1 cup.  Add chopped water chestnuts - 1 can.  ....I just made this for our Easter dinner.  I made several changes based on other reviewers comments.  Sauteed the finely chopped onions in a tblsp of butter slowly until they were starting to brown nicely--about 10 min.  Then added a couple of cloves of finely minced garlic simmered for about 5 minutes.  Added in sour cream, sugar 1/2 tsp salt and fresh cracked pepper to taste.  Stirred in fresh steamed green beans, all the cheese and some french fried onions.  Stuffed this into my round casserole dish and topped with more onions.  From the quick taste test I did on the sauce this should be spectacular!  Also making scalloped potatoes and Alton Brown's Ham with bourbon, gingersnap, mustard  and brown sugar crust.  Can't wait!  Pecan Pie V from Allrecipes for dessert.  Mine and hubby's mouth already watering.

text:
This recipe is AWESOME!  I'm so glad i chose the make this recipe for Thanksgiving this year.  I love green bean casserole, but always felt that the classic Cream of Mushroom soup version was lacking a little something.  After making this recipe, I will never go back to the soup version.  The sour cream and onions added so much more flavor, and the melted cheddar cheese turned out to be delicious (even though I was skeptical about it).  Next time I will try to mix in some fried onions, and/or sprinkle some on top along with the crushed Ritz crackers.  My only revisions to the recipe were that I used a Colby/Monterey Jack blend, and I doubled the amount of cracker/butter topping.  I am addicted!

I was looking for a recipe that didn't call for cream of mushroom soup.  I made this for Thanksgiving and everyone loved it.  My father in law asked to not have the cream of mushroom kind again because he liked this recipe so much.  I used 2 and a half pounds of fresh beans instead of canned. I did put half of the cheese in with the sour cream and sprinkled the rest on top.  And I added  crumbled, cooked bacon pieces.  It was so good.  My husband said that he wants it much more than on special holidays.  GREAT RECIPE!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I really liked this recipe and so did all my family at thanksgiving. It is so different from the traditional green bean casserole. I followed the advice of momma_s and used "FRESH" steamed green beans instead of canned. Reduced the sour cream to 3/4c. Reduced the salt to 1/2 tsp, added black pepper, and 1&1/2 tsp garlic powder with the salt & sugar. Use a large can of french fried onions and mix 1/4-1/2 can into beans, the rest crush with the cracker topping and extra melted butter. Add extra cheese. I made this and also the traditional casserole  made with cream of mushroom soup and no one ate the traditional at all they all devoured this one.

text:
I read through a lot of reviews before trying this out. In the end, I went with these alterations: I used fresh green beans (blanched the night before). I only sprinkled a small amount of cheese on top. I used slightly less sour cream, maybe 3/4 cup. Instead of crackers I used garlic & herb breadcrumbs, and only sprinkled a small amount on top of the casserole. I think the breadcrumbs gave it just a touch of extra flavor. I also sprinkled crunchy fried onions on top about 10 minutes before taking it out of the oven. It was very tasty and I plan to make it again very soon.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
LOVED, LOVED, LOVED this recipe! I made it for the first time for Thanksgiving. It was so fast and simple to put together and baked up perfectly. I doubled the recipe to cook for 15 people and everyone loved it. I took some advice from previous reviews and sauteed the onions in butter first and removed them from the pan. I added 3 Tbsp flour (remember, I doubled the recipe) and then 1.5 cups sour cream. I used 6 cans french style green beans and mixed in 2 cups Colby-Jack cheese (I think it melts better than Cheddar) as well as some crushed up fried onions and a few shakes of pepper. I then topped it all with 2 more cups of cheese and the cracker mix - and more crushed up fried onions. This recipe is going in my favorites! Would be great for a potluck too!

The second time was the charm for me with the following modifications: fresh, frozen green beans, blanched til tender- much better than canned! Sauteed the onions. text:
I followed some of the suggestions left by other reviewers - I used 3/4 cup of sour cream, I sauted the onions before adding them to the flour mixture, and I used fresh (steamed) green beans.  I also threw in some shredded swiss cheese.  It was great!  My husband won't go within 20 feet of a mushroom, so finding a green bean casserole without mushrooms was a challenge.  To me, this one is better than the cream of mushroom version - both the sauce and the Ritz cracker topping.  In addition to mushrooms, my husband despises sour cream but he had no idea that the sauce is comprised mostly of it.  He thought that it was just melted swiss cheese.  Next time I am going to try using only swiss and omit the cheddar.  The recipe is great as is, but can certainly handle minor adjustments and still taste good.  Great recipe!

text:
As written, this would be three stars.  I will make some changes next time.  First, I will omit the crackers/butter all together.  I will replace with French fried onions.  I will cut the sugar down (too sweet!).  Also, I will mix in the cheese instead of layering on top - the cheese layer was too thick!  We used fresh green beans and they were great, though... I would not use canned!  This was such a nice change from the MSG-laden condensed soup recipe!

text:
With a few modifications this recipe is great for a homemade green bean casserole. When I have the time and all the ingredients, I will definitely make this over the canned soup version.

I used dried minced onion instead of the regular onion, picky eaters in the family. As other reviewers suggested, I decreased the sour cream to 3/4 cup, I also added some garlic powder and garlic salt instead of the regular salt. A key change, use the fried onions...I mix one can in with the casserole and cover the top with more! Great crunch!! Such an authentic flavor...Thanksgiving favorite!

text:
I made this for Christmas dinner and I got mixed reviews.  I really enjoyed it.  I thought it was much better than the cream of mushroom variety.  I took advice from others and sauteed the onons first, but I added chopped canned muchrooms to the pan also.  I also used less flour and added the sour cream by taste.  I mixed half of the cheese in too.  I think next time I will use fresh or frozen green beans.  Some really enjoyed it.

text:
This green bean casserole was SO much better than the original with cream of mushroom soup.  It is much more creamy and has so much more taste to it.  Don't be fooled by the number of crackers, it is definitely enough.  In order to get a little of the onion flavor I salted the crackers with onion salt before crumbling them and topping the casserole. 

I will never make the original recipe again!

text:
Due to a Christmas Eve crisis, I had to use the ingredients I had on hand. Therefore, I substituted the fresh chopped onions for French's fried onions and also used the fried onions for the topping instead of crumbled Ritz. I also used only half the shredded cheese as we were also having homemade mac and cheese for Christmas lunch. Everyone seemed to like this version of green bean casserole better than the traditional condensed soup recipe. I may, however, omit the cheese altogether next time, as the sour cream makes the dish rich and creamy enough.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved this dish, I made it for Christmas dinner. Even though I made some modifications, I'm sure it would be 5* just the way it is.  My family likes the mushroom soup flavor, so as I was cooking the onion (only used 1/2), I added about 2 cups of mushrooms that I chopped finely in my food processor.  I cooked those down and the mushrooms made a nice stock that added tons of flavor.  I proceeded to add the sour cream and green beans, then I stirred in about 1 cup cheese and topped with 2 cans of fried onions and heated it in my slow cooker for a couple of hours.  There was no mess to clean up after supper except for the turkey and no rush to have all the dishes ready at once!  Everyone raved about it and said they could NEVER eat the canned soup casserole again.  Thank you!

text:
I made this for Christmas eve dinner and used some of the posted tips.  I used steam fresh green beans and instead of adding cheese on top, I added a handful to the sour cream mix. I also added garlic powder, seasoning salt, and a splash of milk to thin out the sauce mix a little bit.  After it was cooked I added a 3/4 of a can of fried onions in place of Ritz crackers to the top and returned the dish to the oven until the onions were browned.  It was wonderful!  I love the traditional green bean casserole but this was even better.  Next time I would add some diced mushrooms to the mix.  Thank you for the great recipe!

text:
This was pretty good, but even after several changes, the sour cream flavor still really stands out. I do, however, prefer it to the traditional green bean casserole, and my boyfriend LOVED it. I reduced the sour cream to 1/2 cup, added fried onions to the green beans, and instead of putting the cheese on top, I mixed it in with the sour cream/flour/butter mixture with a little bit of milk until it was smooth and creamy, and added it to the beans. I also added fried onions to the cracker topping.

text:
I made almost exactly per the recipe.  I held all the onions in the mixture and topped with the traditional French's crunchy onions since many in my family can't tolerate onions but can pick off the top if they didn't want it. It bakes as a cheesy casserole so it does not look like the picture at all.  I brought it to my very picky in-laws for Thanksgiving - trusting the high grades from so many reviewers.  At first most took a token little bit (one even asked, "where's the green bean casserole?" - wondering where the ole mushroom soup recipe was I'm sure).  Every single man took seconds and one said, "you can always add cheese to everything I eat" - the ritz crackers topping is delicious.  The whole things was great - I scaled to 16 servings and it scaled perfectly - and there was maybe one serving left which says a LOT considering how many Thanksgiving side dishes there are.

text:
I've made this recipe for the past 3 thanksgivings.  Everyone has ALWAYS loved them and requested the recipe, but I've never liked them...at all.  My family requested this dish again this year but I decided to take another reviewers advise and make them with fresh steamed green beans.  OMG THAT IS THE KEY!!!  They were incredible!  I actually had 3 servings and brought some more home with me.  So my changes were:  fresh steamed green beans, extra onions, extra garlic, extra cheese, complete seasoning and I used the French onions, not the buttery crackers.  Great recipe!

text:
I made this recipe over the weekend for friends and everyone seemed to liked it. But like some of the other reviewers, I, too, found the sour cream taste to be overpowering. (i liked it better the next day.) I will also reduce the flour. As is, it came out with the consistency of Play-do when mixed with the butter. But I think this is a great dish to make for a potluck as most people will enjoy it. This is a definite "comfort food" dish. I'm going to try it again with fresh, steamed green beans and as others suggested with a tsp. of garlic powder.
